155332222222222222111.content:
The assassin shadow stepped past the loud watch tower and snuck towards the camp. Under cover of darkness with penumbra magic and wearing an enchanted cloak, it was very unlikely that someone would intercept their attempt on Chrom's life. Which was exactly why he was surprised when he rounded the corner to find a fireball flying rapidly towards his face.

"Apologies." A woman spoke from beyond the ash. "I would prefer to chat about that intriguing shadow spell of yours, but I am afraid you and your friends have reached a proximity dubbed by our commander as the drop everything and stop them with whatever it takes you know who I'm talking to, this is serious."

The assassin blinked. "What?"

The mage pushed her glasses up and sighed, muttering something, then raising a glowing hand. "You have three options," She condescended, speaking slow and sounding out each and every syllable. "Flee--run awaaayyy--, surrender--giiivvee uuuuppp--, or diiiieee."

How dare this woman! He had spent years studying theory and form of shadow--even harder than it sounds--in the hope of serving something so much higher than personal ambition or petty nobility! He was a servant of Lord Grima!

Standing up straighter, organs failing and blood letting, he panted and glared down the woman.

And if this snotty, arrogant, glasses wearing jerk wanted to whine and taunt and moan about Grima knows what, then he'd give her something to whine about!

Quickdrawing, the assassin prepped a dark blast, praying to Grima for courage and strength, and fired away. "LiveanddIEBYVALIDAR--!" The assassin cried as his spell collided with Miriel's in flash of blinding light.
155332222222222222111.title: Miriel v. Assassin #1 Full Fight (HD)

1553322222222222221111.content:
Miriel adjusted her glasses, tying the now unconscious and bandaged soldier up and moving along to link back up with her squad. The perimeter has been breached, which means that the enemies are growing desperate. They must have been a smaller force, expecting little resistance other than the occasional token guard. Perhaps this informant was to be trusted, though, she'd popped up more than once, which was--

She blinked, rubbing her temples and shutting her eyes. It was as if she was talking to that dimwit Vaike drone on about meat or boobs or whatever else crossed his minuscule intellect.

"Miiiriel!" The bumbling oaf called from a short distance away, ax slung lazily over his shoulder. "What's up?!"

Speak of the dullard. "Vaike, where is your squad? Do not tell me you have already lost your squad," An odd coincidence for him to appear like this. Perhaps I sensed his presence subconsciously and fed that information like fuel into the example. "In... all senses of that phrase." Grieve later. Act now.

"Nope!" He guffawed, slapping her brutishly on the shoulder. "They sent me to look for you after the bad guys turned tail and ran."

"Vaike," Miriel's blood ran icy. In the dark of night, there skulked unnatural energy and unholy glow, just beyond what their feeble human eyes could perceie. "They aren't running, they're repositioning."

"Miriel, I don't know wha--."

"They're coming back!" Miriel cried, activating a matter relocation invocation (taking no time to enjoy the ironically comedic rhyme), only for the spell to backfire.

The former assassin's spell was taking effect. Unraveling her spellcraft and redistributing the aether concentrate into physical and intangible form, Miriel's very magick was actively repurposed to transform her body and mind into that of a (brutish barbarian, coquettish cleric, ditzy dancer, vapid villager, dull dark mage.)

Birds chirped, the grass was a little wet, but not irritatingly so, sunlight poked through the branches in a heavenly sort of way, and life was just... good. Even with a reduced capacity for complex thinking, she cherished days like this. They never came enough, now that the war was on.

Of course what was on her mind wasn't so clean.

Chrom! Chrom Chrom Chrom Chrom! Chrooooooom!

"Chrom...!" The pegasus rider giggled, and sat up. "Gonna see Chrom...!" She tilted her head and longed for the man she'd normally more subtly dote on.
155332222222222222111211112.title: Back to camp!

155332222222222222112.content:
"Well, you know what they say about obsession." Robin chided, arms folded with tranquil fury.

The dark mage sighed, tome clutched tight in hand. Careful not to reveal her eagerness, she put on a dull face and repeated the words she'd heard thrice today, "That it's horrific, immoral, unhealthy, and something to--"

"Something to be addressed and dealt with before it causes you or any of your loved ones physical or emotional harm!" Robin waited for a response, and, when none came, blinked and stared at Tharja for a second before moving on his way.

"Little do you know," Tharja giggled, opening the newly acquired tome labeled: Mind into Matter. "This next scheme does neither...!"

Thoughts of a gullible, slow witted, and compliant Robin teased the Plegian as she skulked deep into the forest. Until very recently, she had preferred Robin as such, thinking that it was his mind that she was attracted to, when, in truth, it was his soul. Their bodies were nothing more than a vessel for their love, so, by extension, why leave out their minds? It didn't matter if he couldn't spell/remember his name, or count past ten, or carry a conversation. All there was to worry about was their souls entwining, fusing, and becoming one in an explosion of warmth and love.

And under that, she rushed to gather the last of the ingredients and prepare the spell. The only thing left was to decide what Robin's mind would convert to.

Perhaps a ditzy dancer, too dumb to dream of anything other than her?

Or maybe a brainless barbarian, buffed up and brave.


The choices were neverending!
155332222222222222112.title: Mind into Matter

Perhaps the first warning sign was that the book was 22 gold at a shop deep in a dark alley in a city already well known for illicit and illegal activities. But dark magic always comes with a risk.

And perhaps it would've been wise to note that the book was missing several seemingly imperative pages of lore or background on the single fully intact spell's workings or mechanics. But dark mages were used to gambling on power.

However most obviously of all, Tharja should've been turned off by the fact that the spell, as it was spoken, lit up the air around her with arcane runes and sparkles. But she selectively forgot that dark magic always came with a price.

The Book's true nature was that it contained a lust demon of old who seeked to modify and transform all those it could within its image.

15533222222222222211221.content:
The tome, ancient as it was, had faced its share of hardship. Whilst indestructible, it was indeed changeable, and the adventurers sent to tame the demon had shaped it over the centuries to be a good natured, simple minded, cuddly, lazy overlord of love rather than the ill tempered, calculating, voracious, and ambitious slave driver it once was.

So by her blessing, Tharja's plots were to be halted.

The space around her body was filled with whips of light and words of ancient power. "What?!" She cried.

The runes pulsed.

An explosion from the roots of her hair suddenly made her blonde and spread down her body, softening the features all over. Her thighs plumped, and her lips puffed, and her arms jiggled. Her clothes strained to hold together.

"What's...?" The sorcerer picked through her mind to find the word, but struggled. Struggled, that is, in both searching and trying. Fatigue and sloth were blanketing her body, and ignorance filled the mind. "Going on?"

The light flashed again, and her straining, revealing outfit burst apart by a rapid expansion in bust and bottom. The fabric rearranged itself into a flowy white dress and shawl, accented with gold streaks and embroidered designs. Elegant, to sat the least, it was a soft velvet material and covered near all of her.

With a prod and a poke, Tharja explored her new form and was left stupefied. How could this be? What went wrong? She'd cast the spell good...ly... right...? Once fully processed, she summoned her sharpest sneer and several choice words, but both were lost as the runes burst one last time.

It felt like someone had ripped a bandage off of her heart as every last bit of emotional trauma was opened up. Her thoughts ran faster than ever before to try and cope with the suppressed pain running rampant, but couldn't quite manage. The harder she thought, the slower she thought. Complex words started to fail her. Then the larger ones, and so on, and so forth. Falling to her knees, she clutched her head and shivered out tears. Right when the feeling threatened a breakdown, a soothing alien voice in her head consoled her.

Thoughtlessly, she listened. For five, ten, thirty minutes, the Plegian sat on her heels and listened. Finally, when the light dimmed around her, she took a deep breath in, and then let it go.

It was... like a light shined on her heart.

Suddenly she didn't need intellect, power, money, or anything like that. Because she had food, and she had friends, and she was going to go eat some food WITH her friends!!

Standing up, Tharja was a woman transformed. Her soul and mannerisms were the same, but much... tamer.
15533222222222222211221.title: The Book of Wholesome Chubby Bimbos

"Oh, that's a..." Robin pressed his lips tightly together. "G-Good one, Henry!"

"Yeah...!" Henry wheezed out the last of his laugh and smiled. "And the best part is when he woke up, he couldn't even find where his feet had gone off to because he couldn't walk!!"

The white haired dark mage burst out into hysterics, slamming his fist into the table and clutching his side.

"Ha...!" Robin laughed along, looking around for an out. Fortunately for him, his stalker psychopath entered the room. Great. "Oh...! Tharja... You're here."

"Robby!" Tharja lunged forward, taking his hands and kneeling down. Probably another one of her 'apologies.' Though the aesthetic change was a nice touch. "I'm sooooo sorry!" Sniffling a little, she pouted and looked up with looked to be pretty convincing puppy dog eyes. "I was so mean! And it was to, like, everyone! And everyone's so nice and stuff, and...! And...!"

"Yeah, I'm not buying it." Robin cut her off, squinting and turning back to his bear meat brunch. "But the outfit looks good on you."

"B-B-But I mean it this time!" Tharja cried in that breathy voice--geez, she'd been gone for like an hour. How much preparation could she have done?

Turning back, he looked up and down the woman and pursed his lips tight again. Like all of everything Henry said, there was something deeply and personally disturbing about Tharja's change up. It wasn't the first time she'd tried to change herself for his affections, though this was really upping the ante.

"Oh...!" Henry rose from the ground he'd been laughing and rolling on. "She's right, you know."

There was a pause. "What?"

"Her soul doesn't have that dark magic feel." Henry put a finger to his lips and smiled. "It's all... whole and warm and fluffy now!"

"... When did you get the power to feel a human soul?" Robin felt the blood rush from his face.

"About the same time I made that pact with that demon!" Henry giggled and tilted his head cutely.

"Ha ha...!" Robin laughed nervously, forcing up his lip ends and desperately turning to his plate to find it was gone.

At an oddly respectful distance away, Tharja was sitting with his meal and sniffling and scarfing down plate after plate of lunch.

No one was going to judge her for practicing her dancing, but they had a habit of... staring. Not only the men but the women, too! They didn't seem to be staring like that--err, or for only that--but she wasn't good with compliments!

She wasn't that good... She just knew a lot of tricks and practiced a lot. If they knew what a good dancer looked like, then-- "Tharja?!"

The girl wore clothes just like her--err, except bigger--and looked just like her! Except... bigger! Much bigger! About four or more times bigger! And she, erm, looked a little... slow.

"Do you...?" Olivia shifted weight from one foot to the other. "Need help...?"

Tharja did a lot of weird stuff, for a lot of crazy reasons. Last time she'd had been roped into one of her plans, she'd turned Olivia into a frog for a day and a half. This looked a little bad, but it was possible that she wasn't meant to find her so far out from camp.

"Guh..." Tharja moaned softly, and gently pawed at what looked like a book. "Uh...?" Though it was covered in moss and dirt and... drool?

"Do you want this...?" Olivia inched closer. A teammate was still a teammate, after all. "What even is this thing, Tharja?"

And as Olivia opened the book, her toned dancer belly began to soften. Flesh grew on her svelte thighs, and the formal education she'd picked up in Regna Ferox melted away.

"It's kinda making me feel weird."

15533222222222222211222111111.content:
The duller dancer looked up slowly from the book and at her comrade's blown up body. Something about the way she felt was... wrong... Sort of sluggish and slow and stuff like that, but why? Was she tired?

"I should..." Olivia looked down with discomfort, getting a little look at her softer tummy. "Should..." But out of the corner of her eye, she could see it. It was calling her. It was such a good book. She wanted to keep reading. "Keep reading...!"


Olivia couldn't recall what the book was about or anything specific, but it was just such an interesting read. It really gripped her mind and pulled it into the pages.

The spell's material components are common, household items. A pinch of table salt, a bit of steak bone, and a glass of water.

And at first, it felt very good. It read like a dream. But pages quickly turned to paragraphs, and paragraphs to sentences.

"Take and pour the milk on the bone, and then...!" Olivia said to herself, distantly noticing how tight her bra was becoming.

She couldn't know that her intelligence was dropping and her memory was fuzzing, causing gaps and losses in her knowledge. And her dancer's physique was even worse off. Her flexible, dexterous muscles had puffed up to fat and flab. She looked unable to touch her toes, much less perform--of even recall--any of the intricate dances she'd learned and developed over the years. All was being absorbed into the book's hungry maw.

"Then, um," The pink haired dancer cleared her throat and focused as intensely as she could, but it was as if pushing a boulder uphill. Her mind wasn't strong enough to keep it going, so she pushed to stay stable.

Short, slim and striking, Yenn knows she's smarter than everyone else in the room. Her magical skills have kept her a gorgeous 20 year old for decades, earning her power, wealth and a string of lovers.

So how could she lose both her slim figure and her vaunted intelligence?

Baby Crazy: Yennefer's always wanted to be a mother and has taken many risks to find a cure for her infertility. She finally stumbles onto a successful one, only to fail to realize that the cure will take a very...heavy toll on her figure and slow her wits significantly down. Constant cravings from eating for two will blow the slim sorceress right up, while the hormonal surges and the treatments' interactions with her youth extending potions will take Yen's wits from sharp as a razor to dull as a rock.

A well earned curse: Yennefer has quite a sharp tongue on her and an ability to insult when even slightly annoyed. Unfortunately for her, the fat woman she just called a "Thick as a yard of lard and twice as dumb!" was actually a disguised spirit that believes the raven haired woman needs a taste of her own medicine. If she wants to stop gaining pounds and losing IQ points, she'll need to say she's sorry...which means Yenn is going to get pretty fat and pretty stupid.

In the Harem: Yennefer's been captured by Zerrikanian operatives determined to fill the southern Sultan's harem with famous beauties! The sorceress is not only depowered, but finds that the Sultan prefers his many brides slow of witt and heavy of body. She'll have to find a way to escape...before she gets too big to move and too thick to think of a way out!

A well earned break: exhausted by the war against the Wild Hunt, Yen needs a vacation. So Ciri drops her mother off on a more relaxing world: ours! Yennefer's going to be staying at Vegas, learning too late that on our world she's just a normal woman. To make matters worse, with 24/7 access to luxurius buffets and no ability to magically burn the weight, Yenn's gonna get big. And because Earth has strange things like smart phones, social media, television and video games, Yennefer's going to get very vapid by the time Ciri gets back...

Convergence of the stupid, fat spheres: being so close to the new convergence of the spheres has done something to magic. Every time Yenn casts a spell she gets a little fatter and a little slower, she needs to find a solution before she's...what was she doing again? Eating...right...

The nilfgardian standards of sorceresses: Yennefer is captured by the Nilfgardian Empire, a nation that prefers its sorceresses to be less salacious and more obedient. Over fed to destroy her figure, psychologically tormented to wear down her wits and even worse, forced to age to a flabby, timid 45, what's Yennefer to do?

The Youth Addict: Yennefer examines her beauty one day only to see crows feet, laughlines, gray roots and unsightly sagging staring back. She desperately chuggs a youth potion and realizes she's growing resistant to their effects, requiring an ever increasing amount to stay 20. Extra bad news, the potions are very high in calories and cause appetite increases. Extra, extra bad news, they cause long term disorientation, distraction and stupidity. But Yenn can fix herself if she just makes a medical breakthrough. Now, how did that recipe go again?

The voluntary change: Yennefer's husband Geralt makes a confession to his brilliant, beautiful wife: he's attracted to her wits and slimness, but would be more aroused by her getting dumber and heavier. Intrigued, Yennefer decides to take a waddle on the slower side, sure she'll be able to undue any ill effects. Unfortunately its more enjoyable than she'd have guessed...

Or you could have a story on Triss...
